lecture.title: Lecture 2: Cantor's Theory of Cardinality

page.title: When do two sets have the same size?
page.p: Q: When do two sets `A` and `B` have the same size?
A: Cantor said that two sets have the same size when each of the elements of the both sets can be paired off.

Given two sets \[ \{ a, b ,c \} \quad \text{and} \quad \{1, 2, 3\} \]
Each member of the first set can be paired off uniquely with the second. Recall that in general, no two members of a set are equal.
a &\to 1 \\ b &\to 2 \\ c &\to 3

page.title: Function Review
page.definition: If `A` and `B` are sets, then a function `f:A \to B` is a mapping that assigns to each `x \in A` a unique element `f(x) \in B`.
page.scribe: subtlety warning, in the following definition of direct image, please notice that `f(C)` is notation where `f` is applied to an entire subset.
page.definition:
Let `f: A \to B`, if `C \subset A`, we define the direct image `f(C)`
f(C) &:= \{\forall y \in B,\ \exists x \in C,\ y = f(x) \} \\ &= \{ f(x) : x \in C \}.

The inverse image of a subset `D \subset B` is,
\[ f^{-1}(D) := \{ x \in A : f(x) \in D \}. \]

page.title: Injective, Surjective, Bijective
page.definition:
let `f: A\to B`, where `f` is injective or one-to-one if
\[ f(x_1) = f(x_2) \implies x_1 = x_2. \]
equivalently, the contrapositive
\[ x_1 \ne x_2 \implies f(x_1) \ne f(x_2). \]

if f(A) = B then `f` is surjective or onto. Equivalently,
\[ \forall y \in B,\ \exists x \in A,\ f(x)=y. \]

page.title: Cardinality
page.definition: Two set `A` and `B` have the same cardinality if there exists a bijective function `f: A \to B`
page.p: Here is some short hand for cardinality relations:

ul.li: if there exists injective function `f:A \to B` we write `|A| \le |B|`.

by Cantor-Schroder-Bernstein
if `|A| \le |B|` and `|B| \le |A|` then `|A| = |B|`
A proof of this is beyond the scope of this course, but does follow the familiar notion of inequalities on numbers.
How do we count a set?
If `|A| = \mathbb{N}` then `A` is countably infinite.
If `A` is finite or countably infinite we say `A` is countable.
If `A` is not countable, then it is uncountable.

for the even numbers, `|\{ 2n : n \in \mathbb{N} \}| = |\mathbb{N}|. `
for the odd numbers, `|\{ 2n-1 : n \in \mathbb{N} \}| = |\mathbb{N}|. `
